Lithium sulfur (Li-S) batteries hold great promising for high-energy-density batteries, but appear rapid capacity fading due to the lack of overall and elaborated design of both sulfur host and interlayer. Herein, we developed a novel two-dimensional (2D) hierarchical yolk-shell heterostructure, constructed by a graphene yolk, 2D void and outer shell of vertically aligned carbon-mediated MoS2 nanosheets (G@void@MoS2/C), as advanced host-interlayer integrated electrode for Li-S batteries. Notably, the 2D void, with a typical thickness of ∼80 nm, provided suitable space for loading and confining nano sulfur, and vertically aligned ultrathin MoS2 nanosheets guaranteed enriched catalytically active sites to effectively promote the transition of soluble polysulfides. The conductive graphene yolk and carbon mediated shell sufficiently accelerated electron transport. Therefore, the integrated electrode of G@void@MoS2/C not only exceptionally confined the sulfur/polysulfides in 2D yolk-shell heterostructures, but also achieved catalytic transition of the residual polysulfides dissolved in electrolyte to solid Li2S2/Li2S, both of which synergistically achieved an extremely low capacity fading rate of 0.05% per cycle over 1000 times at 2 C, outperforming most reported Mo based cathodes and interlayers for Li-S batteries. 2D hierarchical yolk-shell heterostructures developed here may shed new insight on elaborated design of integrated electrodes for Li-S batteries. Graphical abstract 2D hierarchical yolk-shell heterostructures were constructed with graphene yolk, 2D void and outer shell of vertically aligned carbon-mediated MoS2 nanosheets as advanced host-interlayer integrated electrode for high-performance Li-S batteries. Image, graphical abstract Keywords MoS2 Graphene Yolk shell 2D heterostructure Lithium sulfur batteries 1 Introduction Lithium sulfur (Li-S) batteries possess great potential as cost-effective and high-energy batteries in various electronics applications due to high theoretical specific capacity (1675 mAh g−1) and energy density (2567 Wh kg−1) from earth-abundant and low-cost sulfur [1–8]. Unfortunately, their practical applications are seriously prevented by fast capacity decay originating from the notorious shuttling effect of highly soluble lithium polysulfides (Li2S n , 3 ≤ n ≤ 8) in electrolyte and non-negligible volume expansion of sulfur during cycling process [3,5,9–13]. To tackle this challenge, various S hosts of nanocarbons, e.g., graphene [14–16], carbon nanotubes [17–19], were developed to improve the interfacial coupling of the polar polysulfides and nonpolar carbon substrates during charge and discharge process. In particular, advanced carbons with unique nanostructures, e.g., core-shell carbon spheres [20], 2D core-shell carbon nanosheets [21], were designed as high-loading sulfur hosts to achieve physical confinement of polysulfides. Besides, inorganic materials with high polar surfaces, such as metal oxides/hydroxide (e.g., TiO2 [22], MgO [23], MnO2 [24,25], and Ni-Co layered double hydroxides [26,27]), metal sulfides (e.g., TiS2 [28], SnS2 [29], Co3S4 [30], and CoS [31]), metal carbides (e.g., W2C [32], and NbC [33]), and metal nitrides (e.g., VN [34], and Co4N [35]), are intensively explored to efficiently modify the surface of nanocarbons, and thus sufficiently enhance chemical interaction with dissolved polysulfides and accelerate the catalytic transition of polysulfides to solid Li2S2/Li2S. For example, the polar and electrocatalytically active CeO2 nanocrystals were inserted into well-designed bimodal micro- and meso-porous nitrogen-rich carbon nanospheres to solve the hurdle of the polysulfide dissolution [36]. Notably, some metal sulfides, e.g., VS2, CoS2, TiS2, FeS, and SnS2, could act as activation catalysts to facilitate the oxidation of Li2S back to S [29]. Furthermore, an interlayer positioned between sulfur host and separator could work as an effective barrier or reservoir for the dissolved lithium polysulfides, resulting in the prolonged life-span of Li-S batteries [37,38]. In this regard, 2D high-aspect-ratio nanosheets, such as graphene [38–41], phosphorene [42], MoS2 [37], boron nitride [43], have been demonstrated as highly efficient interlayers for enhanced Li-S batteries. Despite the great efforts of 2D nanosheets as sulfur hosts and interlayers, the cycling stabilities of high-energy Li-S batteries are still far from satisfactory in actual applications [10,21,26,44–50]. This is because most reported 2D hosts with limited electrical conductivity and low accessible surface area could not provide high-speed electron transport pathways and offer enough interfaces to chemically anchor and physically prevent soluble polysulfide species, in particular, in the case of high loading of sulfur (>70 wt%) [26]. Moreover, severe aggregation of 2D nanosheets usually further reduced the exposed surface area and increased mass transfer resistance from the surface to the interior of electrodes [11]. To address this issue, one recent efficient strategy is to develop host-interlayer integrated electrode based on the same 2D nanosheets for Li-S batteries. As an example, highly conductive graphene and partially oxygenated graphene were employed as current collector and polysulfide-adsorption interlayer, respectively, and the all-graphene based cathode with high S loading of 5 mg cm−2 showed excellent cycling stability over 400 cycles [9]. However, the elaborated design of advanced 2D hierarchically hollow heterostructures as both S host and interlayer, with multiple functional components, enriched exposed surface area, high electrical conductivity and enriched porosity in a nanoscale fashion, for high-performance Li-S batteries, has not yet been achieved. Herein, we rationally designed a novel 2D hierarchical yolk-shell heterostructure (denoted as G@void@MoS2/C), enabled by a high conductive graphene yolk, 2D void and outer shell of vertically aligned carbon-mediated MoS2 nanosheets, as host-interlayer integrated electrode that functioned multi-level physical confinement and chemically catalytic transition of lithium polysulfide for high-performance Li-S batteries. The 2D hierarchical yolk-shell heterostructures were synthesized via hydrothermal growth of MoS2/C tiny nanosheets on SiO2 coated graphene and subsequent etching of SiO2 layer. The G@void@MoS2/C heterostructures could greatly improve the electrical conductivity of S via graphene yolk and carbon mediated shell, provide 2D voids with a typical thickness of ∼80 nm for physical confinement of S/polysulfides and catalytic transition of polysulfides to solid Li2S2/Li2S through the chemical interaction with vertically aligned MoS2 nanosheet shell in the host. Further, the G@void@MoS2/C interlayer further prevented the shuttling effect of lithium polysulfides via both physical blocking and chemical catalysis. As a result, the G@void@MoS2/C heterostructures, simultaneously serving as both S host and interlayer of the integrated electrodes (G@S@MoS2+interlayer), synergistically improved Li-S performance, and achieved superior electrochemical performance, such as high capacity of 1077 mAh g−1 at 0.5 C, and long-term cycling stability over 1000 times at 2 C with a low capacity fading rate of 0.05% per cycle. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of 2D G@void@MoS2/C nanosheets Firstly, the 2D SiO2 coated graphene oxide (GO@SiO2) nanosheets were synthesized by a modified Stöber method [45]. Typically, GO (60 mg) and polyvinylpyrrolidone (0.6 g) were added into a mixed solution consisting of 240 mL ethanol and 30 mL deionized water under stirring for 10 min. Ammonia aqueous solution (12 mL) and tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS, 8 mL) were added to the above solution in succession for the growth of SiO2 layer on GO, and the reaction was kept for 6 h under stirring at 30 °C; the resulting GO@SiO2 nanosheet dispersion was obtained via centrifuging, washing with deionized water and re-dispersing into 100 mL of deionized water. Secondly, ultrathin MoS2/C tiny nanosheets were controllably grown on the 2D SiO2 coated graphene nanosheets. Specifically, 400 mg of glucose, 100 mg ammonium heptamolybdate tetrahydrate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, AHT) and 266.7 mg thiourea (CS(NH2)2, TA) in 15.0 mL distilled water were mixed with 15 mL GO@SiO2 aqueous dispersion, and then the mixed solution was sealed into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. After hydrothermal treatment at 160 °C for 24 h, the product was collected by centrifugation, thoroughly washed with distilled water, and dried at 60 °C. Then, the nanosheets (denotated as G@SiO2@MoS2/C) were obtained after annealing treatment at 750 °C for 1 h under argon flow with a temperature ramping rate of 5 °C min−1. Lastly, HF acid solution (20%) was employed to etch SiO2 layer in G@SiO2@MoS2/C nanosheets, giving birth to the yolk-shell G@void@MoS2/C heterostructures. 2.2 Synthesis of G@S@MoS2/C nanosheets and G@void@MoS2/C interlayer The G@S@MoS2/C nanosheets were prepared by the melt-diffusion method [51]. Typically, the G@void@MoS2/C nanosheets were grinded with sublimed sulfur, and then heated at 155 °C for 12 h in sealed containers with Ar atmosphere. After that, G@S@MoS2/C nanosheets with ∼72 wt% S were obtained. Similarly, the G@S hybrid with loading of ∼75 wt% S for comparison was prepared from graphene instead of G@S@MoS2/C nanosheets, using the above procedure. G@void@MoS2/C nanosheets (6.325 mg, with 33.9 wt% MoS2) were uniformly dispersed in 10 mL ethanol, and vacuum filtered on the PP separator. After drying process at 60 °C for 3 h, G@void@MoS2/C interlayer on PP separator with mass loading of ∼0.5 mg cm−2 was attained. 2.3 Li2S6 absorption test Li2S6 (10 mM) was firstly synthesized by the reaction between S and Li2S in tetrahydrofuran (THF) at 35 °C for 24 h in glovebox. Then, 200 µL Li2S6 solution was mixed with 1.5 mL DOL/DME blank electrolyte without Li salt, then 5 mg G@void@MoS2/C (or graphene) nanosheets were dispersed in the above solution. And the photographs were taken after a certain period of time to record the change of solution color. 2.4 Computational simulation All calculations were performed with CASTEP code integrated into Materials Studio 6.0 package. The binding energy (E) is defined as the energy difference between the MoS2 or graphene models with S specie molecules and the summation of the S specie molecules and model system. 2.5 Material characterization Materials characterization was conducted by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JEOL JSM-7800F), transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2100), X-ray diffraction (XRD, X'pert Pro), scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) with EDX mapping analysis, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi equipped with a monochromatic Al Kα source of 1486.5 eV), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, SDT Q600 V20.9 Build 20) and nitrogen sorption isotherm plots (Quadrasorb SI analyzer). 2.6 Electrochemical measurement Li-S batteries were assembled in an Ar-filled glovebox with the concentration of moisture and oxygen below 1.0 ppm, using CR2016 coin cells with lithium foil as the counter and reference electrode, and G@S@MoS2/C electrode (or G@S electrode) as working electrode. The S mass loading on current collectors was ∼0.8 mg cm−2. The GCD profiles were performed using a LAND CT2001A battery tester. Li-S battery tests were conducted with 1.0 M lithium bistrifluoromethanesulfonylimide (LiTFSI) in 1, 3-dioxolane (DOL)/1, 2-dimethoxyethane (DME) with 1.0 wt% LiNO3 additive as electrolyte between 1.7 and 2.8 V. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy was carried out using a CHI 760E workstation by applying an AC amplitude of 5 mV over the frequency range of 100 kHz–0.01 Hz. 3 Results and discussion The synthesis of 2D hierarchical yolk-shell heterostructures of G@void@MoS2/C via 2D SiO2 layer assisted templating strategy was schematically illustrated in Fig. 1 (a). First, graphene oxide (GO), prepared by Hummers method [2,51], was employed as 2D atomically thick templates for the direct growth of uniform SiO2 coating layer derived from TEOS precursor [21], via a modified Stöber method, giving birth to 2D GO@SiO2 sandwich-like nanosheets. Second, using AHT, TA and glucose as Mo, S, and C precursors, respectively, ultrathin and vertically aligned carbon-mediated MoS2 (MoS2/C) nanosheets were hydrothermally grown on the surface of GO@SiO2 nanosheets to form 2D hierarchically multiple layer-structure GO@SiO2@MoS2/C nanosheets at 160 °C for 24 h [52,53], due to the space-confined effect of in-situ formed polysaccharide matrix from glucose condensation [52]. Finally, 2D hierarchical yolk-shell G@void@MoS2/C nanosheets were obtained after annealing treatment of GO@SiO2@MoS2/C at 750 °C for 1 h under argon, and subsequent HF etching of the middle SiO2 layer. Therefore, 2D hierarchical yolk-shell G@void@MoS2/C nanosheets provide an ideal platform for S host and interlayer in one Li-S battery, in which multi-level physical blocking and chemical interaction would synergistically inhibit the shuttling effect of lithium polysulfides (Fig. 1b). SEM image of GO@SiO2 nanosheets revealed the 2D sandwich-like structure with flat and uniform surfaces (Fig. 2 a), and a thickness of around ∼ 40 nm (Fig. S1). After the growth of MoS2/C layers on GO@SiO2, the surface of 2D GO@SiO2@MoS2/C nanosheets became coarse (Fig. 2b), in which many tiny nanosheets were found on the micro-sheet of GO@SiO2, resulting in vertically aligned sheet-on-sheet structures. It is noted that, with less AHT (60 mg) or more glucose does (600 mg), vertically aligned tiny nanosheets were hardly observed on the micro hybrid nanosheet (Fig. S2). When 140 mg AHT was employed, the G@void@MoS2/C tiny nanosheets were clearly found (Fig. 2c and d). Notably, a typical thickness of 2D void spacing between the graphene yolk and MoS2/C nanosheet shell was ∼80 nm, as visually observed from Fig. 2(e and f), strongly validating the successful synthesis of 2D hierarchical yolk-shell heterostructures. TEM images demonstrated the vertically aligned nanosheet-on-nanosheet structures (Fig. 2g), and high resolution TEM (HRTEM) image of G@void@MoS2/C further displayed ultrathin tiny few-layer MoS2 nanosheets, typically 4–8 layers (Fig. 2h). Also, the layer number of MoS2 nanosheets could be controllably reduced to 2–5 layers with less AHT content (Fig. S3). Importantly, the interlayer space of MoS2 nanosheets was disclosed to be ∼0.98 nm, much higher than that of 0.62 nm of common MoS2 due to the confined growth of MoS2 within an in-situ formed polysaccharide matrix from glucose condensation [52]. Notably, the presence of SiO2 layer on graphene played multiple important roles in the formation of 2D hierarchical yolk-shell heterostructures (Fig. S4). Specially, the thin SiO2 layer greatly suppressed the aggregation and stacking of graphene nanosheets, prevented the direct contact of graphene and MoS2/C nanosheet, and served as 2D template for the formation of 2D yolk-shell heterostructures. Moreover, elemental mapping analysis confirmed uniform dispersion of element S, Mo, and C in the nanosheet (Fig. 2i). XRD patterns were employed to probe the phase changes of pristine GO@SiO2, G@SiO2@MoS2/C and G@void@MoS2/C nanosheets. As shown in Fig. 3 (a), XRD pattern of GO@SiO2 validated the presence of a broad peak ranging from 20° to 30°, assigning to the amorphous nature of SiO2 on GO. After the growth of MoS2/C nanosheets, two distinct peaks appeared at ∼33° and 59° were attributed to the characteristic peaks (100) and (110) of crystalline 2H-MoS2 (JCPDS no.37-1492) [52], both of which were also found in the case of G@void@MoS2/C nanosheets. In addition, after HF acid etching, no phase of SiO2 was observed. TGA result suggested the MoS2 content in G@void@MoS2/C was 44.6 wt% (Fig. 3b). Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm of G@void@MoS2/C indicated high specific surface area of 393 m2 g−1 with the nature of mesopore (<20 nm) (Fig. 3c and d). It is worth noting that the MoS2 content, specific surface area and porous structure of G@void@MoS2/C heterostructures could be finely tailored via changing the content of AHT during hydrothermal process (Fig. S5). XPS of G@void@MoS2/C was shown in Fig. 3(e). It is displayed that, from high-resolution Mo 3d spectrum, several prominent peaks, including Mo 3d 3/2 at 229.15 eV, Mo 3d 5/2 at 232.3 eV and Mo (Mo6+) at 226.3 eV, were detected. Specifically, the presence of Mo (Mo6+) was ascribed to partial oxidization of MoS2 exposed in air [54,55]. High-resolution S 2p XPS spectrum corroborated the existence of S 2p 3/2 signal at 163.8 eV and S 2p 1/2 signal at 165 eV, as well as oxidized sulphate species at 168∼172 eV [2]. The outstanding structural features of 2D heterostructures with conductive graphene yolk, vertically aligned MoS2/C nanosheet shell with enlarged interlayer spacing, and 2D hollow layer-structure space, are highly beneficial for the S host and interlayer for Li-S batteries. To this purpose, we employed G@void@MoS2/C nanosheets as both S host (denoted as G@S@MoS2/C) and interlayer simultaneously for Li-S batteries, resulting in an integrated electrode (denoted as G@S@MoS2/C+interlayer). The S loading into G@void@MoS2/C was conducted at 155 °C in Ar atmosphere, and the sulfur content in G@S@MoS2/C is 72 wt% (Fig. S6). Notably, no free S particles could be found on the surface of G@S@MoS2/C, and the 2D voids of G@void@MoS2/C were completely occupied by solid S (Fig. 4 a and b), originating from the capillary force and strong interactions between S and the hierarchical yolk-shell heterostructures. XRD pattern of G@S@MoS2/C further confirmed the appearance of S (JCPDS no.08-0247) (Fig. 4c). Moreover, benefiting from the 2D shape of yolk-shell heterostructures with high polar surface and high aspect ratio, G@void@MoS2/C hybrids could be readily assembled into the interlayer on commercial polypropylene (PP) separator via vacuum filtration of G@void@MoS2/C nanosheets. As shown in Fig. 4(d), the interlayer, with a diameter of 16 mm and G@void@MoS2/C loading of ∼0.5 mg cm−2 was mechanically robust enough to bear the bending without materials falling off, validating the strong adhesion between G@void@MoS2/C and PP separator. SEM images further disclosed the layer structure of G@void@MoS2/C film on PP separator (Fig. 4e and f). Therefore, 2D hierarchical yolk-shell heterostructures could be potentially used as host-interlayer integrated electrode for Li−S battery (Fig. 1b). The electrochemical performance of G@S@MoS2/C+interlayer integrated electrodes was measured in 1.0 M LiTFSI in DOL/DME with 1.0 wt% LiNO3 additive as electrolyte between 1.7 and 2.8 V. To highlight the superiority of this integrated electrode over 2D flat nanosheets in restricting shuttling effect, we also compared the counterparts of graphene/S (G@S) cathode with 75 wt% S (Fig. S7), and G@S@MoS2/C without interlayer for Li-S batteries, as shown in Fig. 5 (a). It was observed that, G@S cathode, tested at 0.5 C for the initial 5 cycles and 2 C for the subsequent cycles, displayed high initial capacity of 975 mAh g−1, but showed fast capacity fading, only 429, 147, 85 mAh g−1 were kept at 100th, 300th, and 500th cycles (Fig. 5a and b), respectively, while G@S@MoS2/C cathode maintained higher capacities beyond 300 mAh g−1 at 500th cycle (Fig. 5a and b). Further, the G@S@MoS2/C cathode with low content of MoS2 (33.9 wt%) resulted in poor cycling stability (Fig. S8). These results suggested the 2D closed hollow space between graphene yolk and MoS2/C shell worked as a space-confined nanoreactor for the redox reaction between S and Li+, and the resulting polysulfides (e.g., Li2S6) were substantially confined inside and difficult to diffuse out through carbon-mediated MoS2 nanosheet shell due to the physical blocking and chemical interaction (Fig. 5c and d). Importantly, the Li-S performance of G@S@MoS2/C cathode could be enhanced by the introduction of G@void@MoS2/C interlayer between the host and separator. As displayed in Fig. 5(e), the galvanostatic charge and discharge (GCD) profiles of G@S@MoS2/C+interlayer integrated electrode cycled at 0.5 C presented two characteristic voltage plateaus at about 2.3 and 2.05 V, corresponding to the phase transitions from solid S8 to liquid high-order Li2S x (4 ≤ x ≤ 8) and from soluble polysulfides to solid Li2S/Li2S2 [56], respectively. Notably, G@S@MoS2/C +interlayer electrode showed a low polarization of 224 mV (50% of discharge capacity), while G@S@MoS2/C cathode without interlayer displayed shorter voltage plateaus and larger voltage hysteresis of 276 mV. Further, the integrated electrode displayed high initial and second discharge capacity of 1197 and 917 mAh g−1 at 0.5 C, and exhibited 693 mAh g−1 with coulombic efficiency of nearly 100% (Fig. 5f) after 100 cycles. In a sharp contrast, G@S@MoS2/C cathode exhibited low capacity of 477 mAh g−1 at 0.5 C, and capacity retention of only 80% after 100 cycles. Moreover, the integrated electrode (denoted as G@S+interlayer), composed of G@S cathode and G@void@MoS2/C interlayer, disclosed low initial capacities of 821 mAh g−1, and only 547 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles. Therefore, it is demonstrated that the interlayer of G@void@MoS2/C played a key role in restricting shuttling effect and boosting the capacity and cyclability. Because of multi-level physical blocking of polysulfides and catalytic conversion of polysulfides to Li2S2/Li2S with G@void@MoS2/C nanosheet as host and interlayer, the integrated electrode also displayed superior rate capability, such as 1050 mAh g−1 (2nd cycle) at 0.2 C, 847 mAh g−1 (7th cycle) at 0.5 C, 727 mAh g−1 (12th cycle) at 1 C, 637 mAh g−1 (17th cycle) at 2 C, 490 mAh g−1 (22th cycle) at 3 C, 306 mAh g−1 (27th cycle) at 4 C, and 810 mAh g−1 (34th cycle) at 0.5 C, which are obviously higher than the corresponding values of 834 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C, 672 mAh g−1 at 0.5 C, 516 mAh g−1 at 1 C, 186 mAh g−1 at 2 C, 161 mAh g−1 at 3 C, and 612 mAh g−1 at 4 C for G@S@MoS2/C cathode without interlayer (Fig. 6 a). After the current density was switched back to 0.5 C, G@S@MoS2/C+interlayer electrode still delivered exceptional capacities and cycling stability over the subsequent 70 cycles. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy of G@S@MoS2/C+interlayer electrode represented a shorter semicircle in the high-frequency region and a steeper line at low frequency, in comparison with interlayer-free G@S@MoS2/C electrode (Fig. 6b). Specifically, the R ct value of G@S@MoS2/C+ interlayer is ∼98 Ω, much lower than that of G@S@MoS2/C (∼231 Ω), strongly demonstrative of the key role of the interlayer in reducing the internal resistance and facilitating fast mass-transfer process. In addition, two serially-connected Li-S coin cells based on G@S@MoS2/C+ interlayer electrode could light up a light emitting diode (LED) panel with “Li-S” letters (Fig. 6c). Importantly, G@S@MoS2/C+ interlayer electrode, cycled at 0.5 C for the initial 5 cycles and 2 C for the subsequent 995 cycles (Fig. 6d), delivered stable cycling after an activated process from 6th cycle to 50th cycle at 2 C (Fig. S9), and displayed high capacities of 597 mAh g−1 at 50th cycle and 326 mAh g−1 at 1000th cycle, which corresponded to a low capacity fading rate of 0.05% per cycle, outperforming most of reported Mo based materials in cathodes or interlayers for Li-S batteries (Table S1), such as MoS2-S-graphene (524 mAh g−1 at 1 C after 200 cycles with a capacity fading rate of ∼0.2% per cycle) [57], MXene/MoS2-C-S cathode (799.3 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles at 0.5 C) [10], Mo2C/carbon nanofibers (406 mAh g−1 at 1 C after 500 cycles with a capacity fading rate of >0.06% per cycle) [32], MoS2/Celgard separator (401 mAh g−1 at 0.5 C after 600 cycles with a capacity fading rate of 0.083% per cycle), and even MoS2-coated N-doped mesoporous carbon/S cathode with carbon nanotube/chitosan modified separator (501 mAh g−1 at 1 C after 500 cycles with a capacity fading rate of 0.08% per cycle) [58]. To validate the enhanced interactions between G@void@MoS2/C heterostructures and polysulfides, the absorption experiments of Li2S6 based solution with G@void@MoS2/C, graphene and blank electrolyte were conducted, as shown in Fig. 7 (a). Benefiting from the strong affiliations between G@void@MoS2/C and polysulfides, the adsorption dynamic rate of polysulfides onto G@void@MoS2/C extremely exceeded the diffusion rate of polysulfides from the top solution to the bottom G@void@MoS2/C. As a consequence, in the initial 15 min, the solution next to G@void@MoS2/C nanosheets changed into colorless quickly, while the top solution still exhibited yellow. With the extended time of 120 min, the yellow Li2S6 solution become nearly colorless. In contrast, in the case of graphene, the adsorption rate of polysulfides was relative sluggish, the light-yellow color could be seen in the vial after 120 min. It is clearly and visually suggested that the interactions between MoS2 and soluble lithium polysulfides are much stronger than that of graphene with polysulfides. Further, we performed the first-principles calculations to understand the interactions between the various S species and MoS2. Three typical S species of S8, Li2S6, and Li2S were chosen to present various lithium sulfides during charge and discharge processes. And the binding energies between them and MoS2 or graphene were calculated, as shown in Fig. 7(b and c). It is unveiled that the binding energies between MoS2 and each S species (0.94 eV for MoS2-S8, 1.78 eV for MoS2-Li2S6 and 1.74 eV for MoS2-Li2S) were greater than those of between graphene and corresponding S species (0.76 eV for G-S8, 0.98 eV for G-Li2S6 and 1.05 eV for G-Li2S), especially in the cases of Li2S6 and Li2S, suggesting that strong interactions between MoS2 and polysulfides in G@void@MoS2/C heterostructures. The excellent electrochemical performance was ascribed to the rational design of 2D hierarchical yolk-shell heterostructures. Firstly, G@void@MoS2/C with conductive graphene yolk and vertically aligned MoS2/C nanosheet shell is a promising host to significantly improve the conductivity of S, to efficiently confine S/polysulfides in 2D layer-structure voids, and to facilitate chemical adsorption and catalytic transition of lithium polysulfides to solid Li2S/Li2S inside the carbon mediated MoS2 nanosheet shell (Figs. 1b and 5c). Secondly, G@void@MoS2/C interlayer working as internal current collector greatly reduced the internal resistance and accelerated fast mass-transfer process. Thirdly, 2D hierarchical yolk-shell heterostructure for host-interlayer integrated electrode showed the multi-level synergistic effects in the performance improvement of Li-S batteries, in which the S species in G@void@MoS2/C host firstly reacted with Li+ to produce lithium polysulfides during discharge process, and the soluble polysulfides would be physically blocked by the MoS2/C nanosheet shell and chemically adsorbed on graphene and/or catalytically transformed on MoS2 tiny nanosheet shell. Even through the residual soluble polysulfides diffused into the electrolyte from the cathode during the repeated cycles, G@void@MoS2/C interlayer could continuously prevent the shuttling effect of residual dissolved lithium polysulfides via both physical blocking and chemical interactions, thereby maximally alleviating the occurrence of shuttling effect for enhanced Li-S batteries (Fig. 1b). 4 Conclusions In summary, we demonstrated the controllable synthesis of 2D hierarchical yolk-shell heterostructure of G@void@MoS2/C nanosheets as host-interlayer integrated electrode, with multi-level physical confinement and catalytic transition of lithium polysulfide to synergistically alleviate the shuttling effect, for greatly enhanced Li-S batteries. The G@void@MoS2/C nanosheet heterostructure was configured with electrically conductive graphene yolk, vertically aligned ultrathin MoS2/C nanosheet shell with exposed surface area that provided strong interaction and chemical catalysis with soluble polysulfides, and 2D layer-structure internal space that physically confined of polysulfides. As a result, the G@S@MoS2/C+ interlayer electrodes showed high capacity of 1077 mAh g−1 at 0.5 C, and long-term cycling stability over 1000 times at 2 C with a low capacity fading rate of 0.05% per cycle, outperforming most reported Mo based cathodes and interlayers for Li-S batteries. Therefore, 2D hierarchical yolk-shell heterostructures will pave a new way for the elaborated overall design of high-performance electrodes for various energy storage and conversion devices, such as batteries, supercapacitors and catalysts. Wang, ACS Sustain. Chem. Eng.6 (2018) 16828–16837. Zhong-Shuai Wu's Group for 2D Materials & Energy Devices. Our research interests include graphene, 2D materials, energy storage and conversion devices, e.g., flexible and planar micro-supercapacitors and micro-batteries, high-energy supercapacitors, lithium batteries (Li ion, Li-S/metal, solid-state) and new-type Na/K/Al/Zn batteries, and catalysis. Recently, our scientific research concentrates on controlled preparation of high-quality graphene and 2D materials arranging from 2D inorganic to polymer nanosheets, rational assembly of 2D nanosheet-based nanoarchitectures with precise composition, morphology and dimensionality, elaborated exploration of these 2D nanomaterials for the breakthrough energy related devices, and fundamental studies of the charge-discharge reaction mechanism with in-situ characterization techniques.

coredata.dc:description: Lithium sulfur (Li-S) batteries hold great promising for high-energy-density batteries, but appear rapid capacity fading due to the lack of overall and elaborated design of both sulfur host and interlayer. Herein, we developed a novel two-dimensional (2D) hierarchical yolk-shell heterostructure, constructed by a graphene yolk, 2D void and outer shell of vertically aligned carbon-mediated MoS2 nanosheets (G@void@MoS2/C), as advanced host-interlayer integrated electrode for Li-S batteries. Notably, the 2D void, with a typical thickness of ∼80 nm, provided suitable space for loading and confining nano sulfur, and vertically aligned ultrathin MoS2 nanosheets guaranteed enriched catalytically active sites to effectively promote the transition of soluble polysulfides. The conductive graphene yolk and carbon mediated shell sufficiently accelerated electron transport. Therefore, the integrated electrode of G@void@MoS2/C not only exceptionally confined the sulfur/polysulfides in 2D yolk-shell heterostructures, but also achieved catalytic transition of the residual polysulfides dissolved in electrolyte to solid Li2S2/Li2S, both of which synergistically achieved an extremely low capacity fading rate of 0.05% per cycle over 1000 times at 2 C, outperforming most reported Mo based cathodes and interlayers for Li-S batteries. 2D hierarchical yolk-shell heterostructures developed here may shed new insight on elaborated design of integrated electrodes for Li-S batteries.
